p.s: The given poem is Sonnet 138, written by William Shakespeare.
It deals with the topic of love being still love even though it is built on a construct of lies, wichwhich eventually will collapse.
The sonnet starts with a direct message towards the reader.
The speaker states that he still believes his loved one even though he knows she is lying.
He goes on with mentioning negative thoughts his love might have of him, being inexperienced and naive.
This is followed by the speaker naming unrealistic thoughts his loved has about him, being young although she knows that he is of age.
The speaker then again says that he still believes his loved one, wichwhich is connected to his first statement.
In addition he states that the truth is suppressed not only by her but also by him.
Moreover he goes further in saying, why the speakersspeaker's loved one should say that she is lying or why you should say that he is old.
The two rhetorical questions do make his believe that the truth is better than lies, clear.
In the following two lines the speaker states that love consists out of trust, but it does not matter if this trust is fake.
In the last two lines he comes to the conclusion.
Even though they lie to each other, those lies will come back and bring negativity to the relationship.
